text: uh
hi everyone anthony fantano style here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of this black
country new road record ants from up
there this is a new lp from uk rock
outfit black country new road quickly
following up their beloved debut from
last year for the first time which was
met with a very warm reception far
surpassing the high expectations that
fans had of it based on early singles
like sunglasses and science fair for the
first time may have not been a perfect
record but it was so good overnight
black country new road pretty much went
from a band to watch to one of the best
and most exciting the underground had to
offer currently with inventive and
refreshing combinations of post punk art
experimental and post rock not to
mention some of the klezmer bits on this
record too which were amazing the band
also featured the one-of-a-kind vocals
and lyricism of isaac wood whose writing
and performances were so intensely
anxious and detailed that undoubtedly if
you came across a black country's music
over the last year so he made an
impression on you good or bad now
tragically isaac announced his departure
from the band just days before this
album was set to be released it seems to
have been an amicable split with the
band saying they plan to continue
creatively past this point yes it's an
unfortunate change but at least for now
we have this recording this new
recording for black country new road uh
still in one piece and at the very least
on this record they answer the question
of whether or not for the first time was
merely a fluke beginner's luck cause
once again on this album i'd say the
band surpassed expectations hard last
year i did an interview with band
members lewis evans and tyler hyde and
one thing i did glean from it was that
they were really excited about the
directions that the new music was taking
on this record and having heard it now i
can see why this thing rests a lot
harder on the wide array of
instrumentation that the band has access
to outside of the baseline of guitars
and drums horns pianos synth and violin
play a much larger role on this project
and not only is this project more
versatile instrumentally but it pulls
from a larger pool of influences i think
too no longer can haters dismiss black
country new road simply as a slint
rip-off as dumb as that point was to
begin with this new lp sports touches of
minimalism and prague jazz mixed with
the raw emotional chaos of early bright
eyes as well as the rock elegance of
groups such as talk talk plus the
grandiose indie anthemics of wolf parade
and arcade fire but just like with for
the first time this record isn't so much
about its influences as much as how
creatively and uniquely they're brought
together with dynamic performances and
passionate writing from end to end
pretty much every teaser to this record
to one degree or another was fire and
the band dropped so many tracks they
left very little up to the imagination
when the entire thing dropped but still
this whole record comes together
fantastically the intro on this thing is
a tight short instrumental piece in five
with bright horns and a loud chaotic
finish the track contains a harsh beauty
that sets up the theatrical chamber rock
of chaos space marine perfectly this
song is maybe the closest we're going to
get to an indie rock opera this year the
tense beds of pianos and string and
guitar are wonderful and really make the
vivid imagery in isaac's lyrics come to
life especially during the jubilant
chorus so i'm leaving this body and i'm
never coming home again i'll bury the
axe here between the window and the
kingdom of men jesus the track is so
thrilling so edge of your seat so
ergasmic even without it following a
traditional song structure as
instrumentally it just kind of keeps
building up tension from here this track
and many others on the lp show the band
has such a firm grasp of tension and
release the song concord after this sees
the band tumbling further into forlorn
poetic balladry packed with dynamic
swells of horns and piano the lyrics
here are made up of all of these moving
and strange metaphors dealing in longing
loss and departure in life and in love
i'm just so consistently impressed with
isaac's writing i feel like the beauty
of his word speaks for itself i came a
gentle hill racer i was breathless upon
every mountain just to look for your
light but for less than a moment we'd
share the same sky and then isaac will
suffer concord will fly it's a
bittersweet moment on the record that
leads into the incredibly despondent
bread song whose instrumental swells
like a gigantic orchestral lullaby many
of the lyrics on this track seem to
describe this unraveling social
situation that concludes in this immense
moment of rejection oh don't eat your
toast in my bed oh darling i never felt
the crumbs until you said this place is
not for any man nor particles of bread
which is i think a pretty sole uh
crushing comparison uh to
be made even if it is a little
inadvertent the following goodwill
hunting is one of those black country
new road songs that i know some of the
lyrics from it are gonna be stuck in my
head repeating in my head for the next
year because that was very much the case
for multiple songs and lyrical
highlights from the last record she had
billy eilish style moving to berlin for
a little while trying to find something
to hold on to the story of the song has
this odd mix of awkwardness and hope
that
i get off of a lot of great and very
genuine talking head songs but obviously
black country comes to much different
instrumental conclusions the story that
isaac is telling here is
so idyllic and storybook in a way but
his wording here makes it clear that
what he's saying is something he's
merely musing about fantasizing about
and there's a sadness to that especially
as he launches into this diatribe about
how he'd bend over backwards to keep
himself in the mind of this other person
who he's singing about traveling through
space to get home to them another
stellar instrumental performance on the
track too even though this song features
a more standard song structure
the varying beds of instrumentation keep
every section of it feeling fresh and
new there's more instrumental magic to
follow too on the song haldern i love
the repeating minimal horn and piano
lines that the song here floats on top
of which contrasts nicely with the heavy
crunchy guitar riffs in between next
mark's theme is a touching and beautiful
little saxon piano piece that
effectively works as a palette cleanser
before we're hit with the biggest tracks
on the entire record in the last leg now
the three cuts this record closes out
with pretty much make up half the entire
album the place where he inserted the
blade which sounds like spencer krug and
connor oberst in their prime
collaborating on the most grandiose and
depressing song they could possibly
conceive finishing off as well with
these huge group
vocals this track in a lot of ways feels
like an extension of the cutting and
depressive balladry that much of the
record has been made up of so far but
everything about it is pushed to the
brink instrumentally and emotionally
meanwhile the song snow globes a nine
minute monster kicks off with these very
patient
plucked down stroked guitar lines with
some subtle bass underscoring it sounds
kind of like a classic post rock song
from the 90s lift your black country
like antennas to new road so even if
these guitars are instantly recognizable
in a somewhat derivative way very
quickly we start getting uh these
intense
flurries of free jazz drumming coloring
the whole thing actually coloring might
be the wrong word
smothering because the drums are so damn
loud and mixed so aggressively which
even though there are elements of the
song i do love uh might make for my
least favorite part of this entire
record i feel like i'm experiencing the
final crescendo of this track from
inside one of the toms i do have to give
it to the band though because the
gradual progression and performance of
the entire track is still great then
basketball shoes is the multi-phase
12-minute grand finale for the entire
record with the sad twangy midwest emo
guitar lines coloring the intro the
passionate sax lines that build on top
of it lyrical themes of decimation and
concord return the song somehow becomes
even more emo influenced during a riff
switch up at the midpoint really
everything like from the drums the
guitars the lyrics but isaac's vocals
and the extra layers of instrumentation
keep this track feeling like it's firmly
in line with everything else on the
record consistent the distorted
crescendo is ergasmic the uh heavy sax
rock outro is amazing the group vocals
come back once more one of the best
lyrical highlights hits at the very end
of the record too your generous loan to
me your crippling interest
every single song has like some heart
wrenching soul
destroying burning just like ah
it hurts but yeah wow like just what a
great record man what a great impressive
well-performed written and produced
record from
frankly a one-of-a-kind band very sad
that uh you know things kind of panned
out in the way uh that they did with the
departure of isaac but uh once more at
least we were able to
as the audience share this moment with
the band hear this music hear them at
some kind of creative peak hopefully
this unforeseen change doesn't really
like you know kneecap uh the potential
of the group going forward because uh
this record is just stellar and if we
were to lose you know black country new
road uh after this moment that would be
a quite the tragedy especially again
considering how
great this is i mean i i pretty much
loved every single song on this thing to
some degree there were some spots that
ran a little
lengthy or a derivative there's that you
know mixing issue on snow globes i
wasn't too nuts about but still i mean i
i thought this thing was a uh just great
feeling a decent two strong nine on this
one tran position have you given this
